verses.text: In the beginning of the reign of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, king of Judah, this word came to Jeremiah from the LORD:
verses.comment: Some ancient manuscripts have 'Zedekiah' instead of 'Jehoiakim.' Most modern translations follow the Masoretic Text, but the context suggests this prophecy was during Zedekiah's reign. Jeremiah's prophecies often reference Judah's last kings and the coming exile.

verses.text: The LORD said to me, 'Make for yourself straps and yoke-bars, and put them on your neck.'
verses.comment: The yoke symbolizes coming submission to Babylon. Prophets often used physical signs to convey God’s word (see also Ezekiel’s enacted parables).

verses.text: Then send them to the king of Edom, the king of Moab, the king of the Ammonites, the king of Tyre, and the king of Sidon, by the hand of the messengers who have come to Jerusalem to Zedekiah king of Judah.
verses.comment: The foreign kings sent envoys to Zedekiah, perhaps to plan rebellion against Babylon. God’s message is sent to all these nations, showing His sovereignty over all people (see Acts 17:26).

verses.text: Give them this command for their masters, 'This is what the LORD of armies, the God of Israel, says: Tell this to your masters.'
verses.comment: 'LORD of armies' (sometimes 'hosts') emphasizes God's supreme power in heavenly and earthly realms—a recurring theme in Scripture (cf. 1 Sam. 1:3).

verses.text: 'It is I who by my great power and my outstretched arm have made the earth, and the people and the animals that are on the earth, and I give it to whomever seems right to me.'
verses.comment: God reminds the nations of His role as Creator. His sovereign authority is a major biblical theme, echoed in the New Testament where Christ’s Lordship is linked to creation (John 1:3; Col. 1:16).

verses.text: 'Now I have given all these lands into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, my servant. I have even given him the wild beasts to serve him.'
verses.comment: God calls the pagan king ‘my servant,’ showing that even rulers who do not know Him are used for His purposes (cf. Isa. 44:28–45:1 with Cyrus).

verses.text: 'All nations shall serve him, his son, and his grandson, until the time of his own land comes; then many nations and great kings shall make him their slave.'
verses.comment: This foreshadows Babylon’s eventual fall. God raises up and removes kingdoms according to His plan, a truth seen throughout redemptive history.

verses.text: 'But if any nation or kingdom will not serve Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and will not put its neck under the yoke of Babylon, I will punish that nation with the sword, famine, and pestilence,' declares the LORD, 'until I have consumed it by his hand.'
verses.comment: Submission to Babylon was God’s will, at this time, as an act of judgment and means of future restoration. Resistance brings judgment, highlighting the importance of discerning and submitting to God's appointed means of salvation and authority.

verses.text: 'So do not listen to your prophets, your diviners, your dreamers, your soothsayers, or your sorcerers, who are telling you,
'For they prophesy a lie to you, to remove you far from your land, so that I will drive you out, and you will perish.'
verses.comment: False prophecy leads to ruin; true prophecy, obedience, and unity with God's guidance lead to preservation. Spiritual discernment is vital—also, continuous oral instruction (sacred tradition) functions at times alongside scripture for truth (cf. 2 Thess. 2:15).

verses.text: 'But the nation that brings its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon and serves him, I will let remain in its own land,' declares the LORD, 'and it will work it and dwell there.'”
verses.comment: Obedience to God’s revealed will, even when difficult, results in blessing and peace. Submission to divinely appointed authority is a recurring theme in both Old and New Testaments (Heb. 13:17; Rom. 13:1-2).

verses.text: To Zedekiah king of Judah I spoke in the same way: 'Bring your necks under the yoke of the king of Babylon, and serve him and his people, and live.'
verses.comment: God directly addresses Judah’s king, underscoring the need for unity and faithfulness to the divinely established order, anticipating the greater King who brings true unity (John 17:21).

verses.text: 'Why will you and your people die by the sword, by famine, and by pestilence, as the LORD has spoken concerning any nation that will not serve the king of Babylon?'
verses.comment: Persistent refusal of God's path leads to judgment. God’s warnings come through His prophet, echoing the importance of listening to divinely appointed teaching and shepherding.

verses.text: 'Do not listen to the words of the prophets who are saying to you,
'For I have not sent them,' declares the LORD, 'but they are prophesying falsely in my name, that I may drive you out and that you may perish, you and the prophets who are prophesying to you.'
verses.comment: False teaching brings destruction—God will preserve only what is built on true, divinely authorized doctrine (see Matt. 16:18 for the church built on ‘the rock’).

verses.text: Then I spoke to the priests and to all this people, saying, 'This is what the LORD says: Do not listen to the words of your prophets who prophesy to you, saying,
'Do not listen to them; serve the king of Babylon and live. Why should this city become a ruin?'
verses.comment: Jeremiah urges obedience; unity with God's ordained plan saves the people and preserves the temple. Spiritual and physical unity are significant in both Old and New Testament faith communities (John 17:22-23).

verses.text: 'If they are prophets, and if the word of the LORD is with them, let them intercede with the LORD of armies, that the vessels remaining in the house of the LORD, in the house of the king of Judah, and in Jerusalem, may not go to Babylon.'
verses.comment: True prophets' prayers are powerful (cf. James 5:16). Priestly mediation and intercession are shown as authoritative means of preservation—pointing to the New Testament ministry of prayer and intercession (1 Tim. 2:1; Heb. 7:25).

verses.text: For this is what the LORD of armies says concerning the pillars, the sea, the stands, and the rest of the vessels that are left in this city,
verses.comment: These sacred objects had great symbolic and liturgical significance. Their loss pictured the withdrawal of God’s presence, which would be restored fully only in the new covenant worship (see Heb. 9:1-12).

verses.text: which Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon did not take when he carried away into exile Jeconiah son of Jehoiakim, king of Judah, from Jerusalem to Babylon, along with all the nobles of Judah and Jerusalem—
verses.comment: A reference to an earlier exile; the final destruction and exile would come later. The continuity between Jerusalem’s old temple items and the promise of restoration hints at both continuity and fulfillment (prefiguring fulfillment in Christ, John 2:19-21).

verses.text: Yes, this is what the LORD of armies, the God of Israel, says concerning the vessels that are left in the house of the LORD, in the house of the king of Judah, and in Jerusalem:
verses.comment: God’s promises about the sacred vessels show that He is still in control, even in exile. His house and its furnishings foreshadow the unity and continuity of worship that finds fulfillment in the New Covenant.

verses.text: 'They shall be carried to Babylon and there they shall remain until the day I visit them,' declares the LORD. 'Then I will bring them up and restore them to this place.'
verses.comment: God’s promise to restore the vessels prefigures restoration and renewal; His faithfulness assures that what is true and set apart will be restored in the fulfillment of time. This restoration echoes the hope found ultimately in Christ, through whom God brings His people back into true worship (cf. Heb. 9:24; Rev. 21:1-3).
